00019 
00020 /**
00021 
00022 
00023  @page build  OCTEON SDK config and build system
00024 
00025 @section build_intro 1. Introduction
00026 
00027  * The OCTEON SDK config and build system builds the simple executive library,
00028  * in the common directory if the library is not present or any changes made
00029  * to the simple executive files.
00030  *
00031  * The build system for simple executive supports building 64-bit and 32-bit
00032  * applications. By default 64-bit applications are built and the object files
00033  * are placed in the 'obj-octeon' directory under $OCTEON_ROOT/executive directory.
00034  *
00035  * When the envionment is sourced with OCTEON II model, for example OCTEON_CN63XX,
00036  * the application is compiled with -march=octeon2 ISA. This toolchain option
00037  * generates OCTEON II specific instructions. The application will not run on
00038  * OCTEON and OCTEON Plus models, will run on OCTEON II and OCTEON III processor.
00039  * The object files and library are placed in the 'obj-octeon2' directory under
00040  * $OCTEON_ROOT/executive directory.
00041  *
00042  * Based on the configuration, specific to the application, respective
00043  * functions are linked into the application from the library.
00044  *
00045  * To build the library in a different directory pass OCTEON_EXEC_DIR=DIR
00046  * to make command. If "OCTEON_EXEC_DIR=mylibdir make" command is invoked,
00047  * then object files and library are created under mylibdir directory.
00048  *
00049  * The build system supports building for either compile time or runtime OCTEON
00050  * model selection.  Please see the "Supporting multiple OCTEON models" section
00051  * of the simple executive documentation page and octeon-model.h for more details.
00052  *
00053 @section build_2 2. How to use
00054  *
00055  *
00056  * To use the build system, the application Makefile should use the template provided below.
00057  * The template provides the proper order of inclusion for the various Makefile fragments
00058  * provided by the build system, such as common.mk, cvmx.mk and application.mk.  If additional
00059  * components are used in the application, the component will provide a component Makefile
00060  * fragment to be included as well.  Below is the application Makefile template showing
00061  * an application target "app_exe" being built from "app1.c" and "app2.c":
00062  *
00063  *
00064 @code
00065 
00066 #
00067 #  application Makefile
00068 #
00069 #  $Id: doc-build-system.h 128470 2015-11-19 23:27:42Z cchavva $
00070 #
00071 #    subdirectory config/ contains all the configuration header files.
00072 #        for example config/cvmx-config.h contains the system resource config,
00073 #        config/executive-config.h contains the simple executive config,
00074 #        config/global-config.h contains global config across components,
00075 #        config/comp1-config.h contains component config for comp1.
00076 #    subdirectory obj-octeonX/ contains intermediate build and library files.
00077 #
00078 
00079 #  default target
00080 
00081 default: application-target
00082 
00083 #  standard common Makefile fragment
00084 
00085 include $(OCTEON_ROOT)/common.mk
00086 
00087 #  include needed component Makefile fragments
00088 
00089 dir := $(OCTEON_ROOT)/executive
00090 include $(dir)/cvmx.mk
00091 
00092 # dir := $(OCTEON_ROOT)/components/comp1
00093 # include $(dir)/comp1.mk
00094 #
00095 # dir := $(OCTEON_ROOT)/components/comp2
00096 # include $(dir)/comp2.mk
00097 
00098 #  application specification
00099 
00100 TARGET        =  app_exe$(PREFIX)
00101 
00102 OBJS          =  $(OBJ_DIR)/app1.o $(OBJ_DIR)/app2.o
00103 
00104 CFLAGS_LOCAL = -g -O2 -W -Wall -Wno-unused-parameter
00105 
00106 include $(OCTEON_ROOT)/application.mk
00107 
00108 #  clean target
00109 
00110 clean:
00111     rm -f $(TARGET)
00112     rm -f $(CVMX_CONFIG)
00113     rm -fr $(OBJ_DIR)
00114 
00115 @endcode
00116 
00117  *
00118  * Some items have special meaning:
00119  * - application-target: This target depends on the TARGET variable and provides a way to
00120  *   intercept the default make target prior to the value of TARGET being defined.
00121  * - dir: For each component needed by the application, this variable needs to be set to
00122  *   where the component source is located.  Note the required immediate evaluation assignment syntax.
00123  * - TARGET: The name of the application to be built.
00124  * - OBJS: Each application source file should have its corresponding object file listed here.
00125  * - CFLAGS_LOCAL: CFLAGS that will be used for building files listed in OBJS.
00126  *
00127  * This build system should be used for applications that require cvmx-config.h (system resource config).
00128  * All SDK examples that need cvmx-config.h use this build system.
00129  *
00130 
00131 
00132 
00133 
00134 @section build_2_1 2.1 Environment variables and global configuration
00135 There are several environment variables that can be used to add options
00136 to various stages of the build.  These are:
00137 
00138  - OCTEON_CPPFLAGS_GLOBAL_ADD
00139  - OCTEON_CFLAGS_GLOBAL_ADD
00140  - OCTEON_ASFLAGS_GLOBAL_ADD
00141  - OCTEON_LDFLAGS_GLOBAL_ADD
00142 
00143 The contents of these variables (if defined) will be added to the respective FLAGS variable in the build system.
00144 The build system current uses OCTEON_CPPFLAGS_GLOBAL_ADD for the following configuration options:
00145  - runtime model checking: Runtime model checking is optionally enabled by the env-setup script.  This is done
00146   by adding the "-DUSE_RUNTIME_MODEL_CHECKS=1" to this environment variable. This is the
00147   default behaviour.
00148  - runtime checking of POW consistency, CSR addresses, and other parameters:  To enable this, pass the --checks
00149    argument to the env-setup script.  This is _strongly_ recommended, as it can identify coding errors that may be
00150    difficult to find otherwise.
00151  - To use 1-1 TLB mappings for simple executive application:.  Its disabled by default. To enable
00152    use of 1-1 mappings, the string "CVMX_USE_1_TO_1_TLB_MAPPINGS=1" to the environment variable.
00153    This will cause the application initialization code to setup 1-1 mappings, and also cvmx_phys_to_ptr()
00154    and cvmx_ptr_to_phys() to do the proper convertions.
00155 
00156 
00157 @section build_3 3.  Config system
00158  *
00159  * Each component in the SDK may have configuration settings, which are specified in the
00160  * cvmx-config.h header file.  When creating a new application, a config subdirectory
00161  * should be created, and application-specific config header files should be placed in the
00162  * config subdirectory.  Templates (starting points) for such config header files can be found
00163  * in the component directory as component-config.h.template.  For example, the simple executive's
00164  * configuration header file template is found at OCTEON-SDK/executive/executive-config.h.template.
00165  * The application should make a copy of it in the application directory as config/executive-config.h.
00166 
00167 @code
00168 Example: creating an application that uses simple executive
00169 
00170 % mkdir application
00171 % cd application
00172 % mkdir config
00173 % cp $OCTEON_ROOT/executive/executive-config.h.template config/executive-config.h
00174 
00175 (then edit executive-config.h to tune the flags/settings as appropriate for the application)
00176 
00177 @endcode
00178 
00179 
00180  *
00181  * The build system will take care of creating a system resource header file, by running the cvmx-config
00182  * tool on all the configuration header files in the application's config subdirectory.  The automatically
00183  * generated file will be config/cvmx-config.h.
00184  *
00185  * The application can specify its own config/resource requirements via this system as well.
00186  * All header files of the form config/*-config.h will be picked up by the config/build system.
00187  *
00188  * Each component-config.h file contains two sections: first, the component configuration section
00189  * should detail the various compilation flags and settings that can be defined to control the
00190  * behavior of that particular component.  Flags may be used to enable/disable features, settings
00191  * may be used to define parameters required for that component.  This section is normal C code.
00192  *
00193  * The second section contains the resource requirements of the component.  This section
00194  * is not C code, and is therefore bracketed by \#ifdef CAVIUM_COMPONENT_REQUIREMENT/\#endif.
00195  * The resource requirement section may be split into another file and included in the
00196  * component-config.h file.  This is done for the simple executive with the resources
00197  * described in the cvmx-resources.config file that is included by executive-config.h.
00198  *
00199  * The resource requirements are always specified in the format of section name "cvmxconfig",
00200  * followed by open brace, followed by the resource requirement specifications, then finally
00201  * ending with a close brace.
00202 
00203 @code
00204 cvmxconfig
00205 {
00206     ... resource requirement specifications go here ...
00207 }
00208 @endcode
00209 
00210  * There are three types of resources requirements: fpa, fau, and scratch.
00211  *
00212  * Each resource specification start with the resource type, followed by the definition name
00213  * (the name of macros that will end up in the generated cvmx-config.h), followed by a series
00214  * of name = value pairs, terminating with semicolon.
00215  *
00216  * For fpa resource specification, the following name value pairs are recognized:
00217 
00218  @code
00219  pool = <integer>        ranges from 0 through 7, specifies the required FPA pool number, for pools that must be fixed.
00220  size = <integer>        specifies the size of buffers in the pool in number of cache lines.  (default: 1)
00221  priority = <integer>    ranges from 1 through 8, specifies the desired priority (1 = highest priority).  (default: 8)
00222  protected = <boolean>   if true, no other fpa resource can map to the hardware pool assigned to this resource.  (default: false)
00223  description = <string>  doubly quoted string, which will appear as comment in the generated cvmx-config.h.
00224 
00225  <boolean> can be "true", "yes", or "1" for true, and "false", "no", or "0" for false.
00226  @endcode
00227 
00228  @code
00229  Example fpa resource specification: the packet buffer pool
00230 
00231             fpa CVMX_FPA_PACKET_POOL
00232                     pool        = 0
00233                     size        = 8
00234                     priority    = 1
00235                     description = "Packet buffers";
00236 
00237  @endcode
00238  *
00239  * For fau resource specification, the following name value pairs are recognized:
00240  *
00241  @code
00242  size = <integer>        specifies the number of bytes per element.  (default: 8)
00243  count = <integer>       specifies the number of elements.  (default: 1)
00244  description = <string>  doubly quoted string, which will appear as comment in the generated cvmx-config.h.
00245  @endcode
00246 
00247  @code
00248  Example fau resource specification: an array of 8 bytes for output queue index
00249 
00250             fau CVMX_FAU_REG_OQ_INDEX_BASE
00251                     size        = 1
00252                     count       = 8
00253                     description = "FAU registers for the position in PKO command buffers";
00254  @endcode
00255  *
00256  * For scratch resource specification, the following name value pairs are recognized:
00257  *
00258  @code
00259  permanent = <boolean>   if true, this scratch location cannot be shared with another scratch resource.  (default: true)
00260  size = <integer>        specifies the number of bytes per element.  (default: 8)
00261  count = <integer>       specifies the number of elements.  (default: 1)
00262  iobdma = <boolean>      if true, this scratch location can be used as an IOBDMA destination.  (default: true)
00263  @endcode
00264 
00265  @code
00266  Example scratch resource specification: output queue buffer preallocation
00267 
00268             scratch CVMX_SCR_OQ_BUF_PRE_ALLOC
00269                     size        = 8
00270                     iobdma      = true
00271                     permanent   = true
00272                     description = "Pre allocation for PKO queue command buffers";
00273  @endcode
00274  */
